text: one of the things I always find very
interesting is people who have great
anxiety when they're in their teens that
they don't yet know what they're going
to do with their life but actually very
few people know what they're going to do
with their life when they're 17 18 19 20
years old uh in fact if you look back at
a lot of people who ended up with a very
interesting trajectory someone like
Harry Truman one of our great presidents
uh he didn't know what he he was going
to end up in politics he certainly
didn't know what he was going to be
doing when he was in his teens and
that's true for a lot of people it was
certainly true for me if you would have
asked me when I was 17 years old whether
I'd be doing what I'm doing
today there's no way I would have come
up with this even on a list of a hundred
possibilities with one caveat the one
thing I Knew by the time I was 17 16 15
probably by the time I was eight is I
was infected with the incurable disease
of
curiosity and everything in my life has
been driven by a Relentless non-stop
curiosity I just got to figure stuff
out my influences really began in my
college Years and in my 20s because the
role modeling I got as a kid was almost
negative role modeling it was what to
not be and what really captured my
attention uh were people who had really
high standards of values and really high
uh levels of intellect and curiosity and
so it was generally great teachers and
great professors I had had a wonderful
Professor when I was a in college my
freshman year named John Goen and I'll
never forget this moment when when I I I
spouted off something about Hegel in a
philosophy seminar and and and uh uh
John Goen uh his name was Goen if I said
Gardener a moment ago John Goen uh had
me come to his office he was the
Ombudsman professor of philosophy he was
a Meritus and he sat me down in his
office and he said uh a word to the wise
uh Mr Collins now was this 18-year-old
kid freshman in college one ought not to
speak about what one does not know and
then shuffled me out of his office and I
guess probably I've been really blessed
by mentors starting at about that age
who always would smack me upside the
head whenever I would get off track
whenever I needed a bit of correction
and I I I listened to those people in my
early 20s uh I built a personal board of
directors uh as a replacement I didn't
have a particularly great uh uh father
role model so I decided to build one to
invent one to create one from scratch
and so the way I did this was to
assemble a board of directors of people
who I uh would really want to look up to
whose values I wouldn't want to let down
I put seven people on that personal
board and then that personal board of
directors was the mechanism that I used
as a way to guide myself through life
combined with reading a lot of
biographies so if you didn't get those
Role Models you can actually invent them
and if you happen to be in your mid-20s
which is when I was when I came up with
the personal board I I really recommend
it as one of the key mechanisms in
life I'm hoping it
comes uh you know I mean is one of the
really interesting things about uh
feeling successful I my own sense is
that people who are successful largely
don't feel successful uh they're really
motivated by the work itself and uh to
me the ultimate reward for my work is
that I get to keep doing it I remember
when I asked uh one of my mentors uh
somebody who I always look up to the
great Peter Ducker he was 86 years young
at the time he had reset the whole field
he's the most significant figure in the
field of management for a hundred years
uh and I asked Peter du at his age 86 at
that time which of your 26 books are you
most proud of and he said the next one
and he never felt that he got it right
even at 86 years old and he wrote 10
more books so I think even if you ask
somebody like Ducker at age 86 was there
a point at which you felt the most
successful the response is no I'm I'm
more interested in what I haven't done
what I haven't created what comes next
I'm always a work in progress trying to
create something that I will be
ultimately really happy with and if
you're a creative curious person that
day will never
come it's interesting to wrestle with
the question of when you've struggled
the most because in a creative process
in a research process an intellectual
process which is what we engage in uh
the whole kind of point is to find the
struggle and it's when you don't know
the answers where you live in lots of
data and and and and and and you're
trying to make sense of things I
remember when Jerry poris and I were
were really really struggling to get the
ideas and built to last to come clear
and there's this point of great creative
angst where you feel you're never going
to see what what the data ultimately is
going to lead to and and you struggle
and you try to create and then I
remember taking a whole bunch of slips
of paper and and and putting all kinds
of data notes on them and taking a
gigantic table and laying out on the
table all of these little slips of paper
and trying to find ultimately the
pattern that they represented and
eventually they began to separate into
two sides these seem to belong on this
side of the table those seem to belong
on that side of the table and eventually
they sorted to the two sides and out of
that came the insight about great
Enterprises preserve something that is
deeply core and at the same time are
always stimulating progress and change
and moving forward and it's the tension
between those two that Mak something
great well the struggle that struggle
lasted for a year of just trying to make
sense and the interesting thing about it
is that if you're engaged in that kind
of work you're always in a struggle and
if it's not a struggle uh you're really
not pushing yourself so the question of
when I've struggled the most is I I hope
it's tomorrow
